bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, December 8, 1879

div1.p: Reed is glad Emilie and their son made it safely to Norfolk. He describes his friend Cruse as well as several women who have been kind to him. He encourages his wife to have her photograph taken and to attend the theater.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, December 8, 1879
div1.p:
Yesterday's mail brought two mighty
sweet letters from little lovie, but somehow or other they were
a mighty long time on their journey- One was dated Novr 15th &
was consequently 22 days in Transit, and the other dated Novr
20th & was 17 days “acoming”- Now, precious lovie, can you
not hid upon some other days for writing, so that I can
hear from my darling in shorter time?- If you will write
on Thursdays and Sundays, I think it will answer much
better and I will then get my letters in 13 or 14 days, as I did
right along a month or two ago. I am now sitting at the
same table with Dr McPherson - he on one side and I on the
other, and both writing to our sweethearts for dear life! I tell
you, lovie, the way the pens are scratching and the ink fly-
-ing, is a caution to rate! We are both, too, using this
small, fragile paper, which was never intended to serve
any other purpose than to write “compliments” to young
ladies and ask whether it “would be agreeable to escort
them to church, this eve”- “Hesche”! I tell the Doctor, that
it was a rash thing for me to have commenced on this
terrific “baru-door” paper, as I am certain I will have
to leave some part of it blank; and that would be a
great disappointment to “Mrs. Piggie”- (I guess, lovie, dear,
if I am “Mrs Piggie”, that you must properly be called
“Mrs. Piggie”? No? “I want to know”! “Hesche, enchase”!) At
the rate at which the doctor's pen is whirling along
the lines, I think he is certainly going to write 40 pages!
that girl of his certainly “lays herself out”, as it were,
in letter writing- He only writes one letter a week,
& that is generally short, while she indites to him
three long letters, every week; some of them containing
12 to 20 pages! Now what do you think of that, lovie?
My own private opinion is that such condescension
on the part of one's sweetheart, would spoil any
man, and make him think that he is really of more
importance than is really the case- Men are vain
(and women are, too, Mrs. Piggie,) and they generally puff up
their little “Cancasses” considerably, if they suppose that
they are of absolute necessity to any particular dam-
-sel- show that is not the way for a “fine gal” to do,
if she expects to keep the “upper hand”, as it were, of
her “enawored sevain”, so to speak,( and I am told, lovie,
that woman is very fond of exerting a little authority, as
it were, over the “gent” who prostrates himself before
her shrine of beauty and virtue!) “How some dives”, as the Monkey
remarked to the parrot, “its none of my business,” how many
times a “fellow's” “gal” writes to him: only I am mighty sure
that I “once upon a time” wrote to a nice “fine gal”
who just made me “Knuckle down”, as it were, & write to
her, every day, and what is very differ true, I loved her
all the more for it! But “fine gals”, lovie, differ from
each other as muches as peaches on a tree; and of course,
a “gent” must judge for himself what Kind of a peach
he is going to pluck! So you are going to get real mad
with “Señor Piggie” for saying that you took the first
“chance” that came along? how, “Mrs. Piggie”, how dare you
call me a “chance”? I "aint no “chance”, now! Call me
“Member of Congress”, “General Grant,” “Apache Indian,” or
Even “Post Trader”, but don't call me a “chance”! I can't
stand it, lovie! I am, at least, “an opportunity,” or an “offer”-
or a “gent”! Well, I never thought that “Señora Piggie” was
going to “dub” “Señor Don Piggie”, a “chance”! I think we are
about even lovie, & you just take this Kiss, & put it away
safely & don't you tell anybody about it! said you must
remember, lovie, that when “first we met beneath the ap-
-ple blossoms, Kathleen”, you had scarcely reached the
“shank of the evening,” of your beauty and charms, so to
speak- You, poor, fluttering little dove, had just secured
your perch upon a spray of lilac, (“I want to know”!)
And was only warbling the first sweet notes of your mor-
ning “ditty,” when along came a hungry hawk, by
name, “whi OT”, &c, & ruthlessly tore you from that
“sweet-potatoe vine”, and bore you away to his “eyrie”
perch! “Eyrie perch” is very good, darling little wifie, espec-
-ially when applied to a "chiquita log-casa (observe
the exquisite blending of the English & Spanish langua-
ges, producing wondrous harmony, lovie,) at Camp Apache.
But, lovie says that she is satisfied and so am I, and “thats
what's the matter”- Hesche! Didn't float once more adown
the yellow-haired Mcherrin's winding banks, lovie, dear? and
dis't list to the full-throated notes of the songsters in-
-habiting bows over its waters pendent? I tell you, wifie,
that last sentence was a “squelches”! I thought at one
time that I could never bring it to a happy conclusion!
Ask son if he can parse it, for mama- Does Captain Lang-
-horne still “ride & rule” the mcherrin's golden evavelets?,
Son has absolutely become a very “distingué” traveller! You
will have to get him a copy of the “Tourist,” if he takes
many more journeys- And eye-glass would also be appropriate.
Am so glad to know that mother & son arrived safely at Nor-
-folk, after a pleasant journey, and that Pa Reed met them
at the Depot- From what he writes to me, he is not only proud
of his grandson, “Sir Lawrence Reeds”, but also of his daugh-
-ter-in-law, “Sir Lawrence's” Mother! He always speaks in the
most affectionate manner of my pretty wifie, and I know
she occupies a place in his affection second to none of his
children. You mustn't forget to give husband a full descrip-
-tion of your pretty, new dress, for he will take the greatest
interest in knowing how his little darling is dressed & how
pretty she looks. Don't tell me, lovie, dear, that you dont want
your picture taken again- Come, that will never do- You
forget, precious, that you have never had one taken by a
first-class photographer- I want a full view of your
face taken- I mean a full, front face- not a profile-
It must be done, & husband won't take “no”- & his precious
darling must not refuse- Have them taken & send them
along- I want them to adore my mantel with, & I must
have them! “Hesche! Euchaw”! “Booligs”! Tuesday Morning 9th 1877.
I must get to work and finish my darling's letter, this mor-
-ning. It is a dreary, cold morning at Apache- Is raining
now and I think will soon change to a real good fall
of snow, which will be very appropriate for the Christmas
Season. Mr Cruse starts, this morning, for San Carlos, for pur-
pose of taking back to the Agency Lt. Gatewood's Scouts, whose
term of enlistment has expired- I know “little Tomie” Cruse,
as we call him, will have a cold, dreary ride to-day-
I wish you could meet him, darling- He is the most per-
fect boy you ever saw; and his laugh! why it is simply
contagious! He utters such a hearty roar, when he
hears anything funny, that every one else is compelled
to join in the laugh with him- His little pet dog, “Joe”,
who sleeps with him, every night, has been left in my
charge, during his absence, & is now sitting up in my
front window, and whining as if his heart would
break. Lt. C. & I are great friends- with all his boyish
ways & amusements, he possesses considerable strength
of character- He is strickly temperate and does not
indulge in gambling, and he declares that he will never
fall into these two vices- Does not use tobacco, either.
He & I frequently indulge in a quiet game of Euchre
together & enjoy ourselves very much. I had some desire
of going to San Carlos with him, but the cold weather fright-
-ened me off. Do you know, lovie, dear, that I haven't sent
for a single Christmas present for any of the ladies at the
Post? I suppose I should have sent for a pretty book or
something of that kind, for Mrs. Harrison & Mrs. Heutig, but I
really had forgotten all about it. I don't like to be considered
stingy, and they have both been very kind to me- Besides, those
little tokens of esteem from one to another makes life some-
-thing better & brighter & awake to light the better side of our
Nature- Mrs. Harrison will start on the 22nd for Tucson, for
the purpose of spending a month or so with Colonel Cavr, 6th
Cav. & his wife, at Lowell, our old “Camping ground”- Mrs.
Carr & Mrs. Harrison are old friends & she anticipates a very
pleasant time at Lowell, this winter-day very glad she
has received the invitation, for I know that a short respite
from Apache monotony will do her much good- Mrs. Heutig
will go down later, if her health sufficiently improves- I have
had her under treatment for womb trouble for about 6 weeks-
She is now much better & her improvement is gratifying.
A change of climate, food & faces would do her much good
too. Who do you suppose, precious wifie, will act as Mrs.
Harrison's Escort to Lowell? Why, the redoubtable Champion
of beauty & wit, “Adam”, the first man! It so happens
that he has been ordered down to Lowell on Court Mar-
-tial duty- Court meets- Jan. 5th & Mrs. H. seizes this
chance of going down- I'll bet my weight in “dried pea-
-nuts” that “Adam” “pops the question” to the widow before
he gets to Lowell! But I don't think that he will ever suc-
-ceed- I am so glad that my darling wifie had the chance
of seeing Miss Neilson act as “Juliet”- I saw her in Brooklyn,
in 1874, in the same character, and I thought her acting very
fine. How many theatres are there in Norfolk, lovie? Is
there only one? I shouldn't think that a City of its size
could support more than one theatre- Always go, my darling,
when there is acting or singing worth seeing, and enjoy
yourself to your precious heart's content. Husband
wishes his sweet, loving wifie, a merry, merry Christmas,
and his darling little son the same! May you both live
to enjoy many happy repetitions of the coming season,
with your ugly old Mantee! Don't forget, Mama, to get
darling little son some nice little present- Make his dear,
innocent little heart as happy as possible- Hang up
his sweet little stocking & fill it full of pretties and
Charge it all to papa! Love his life, how I would like
to see it hanging up! Hang up your “feet little stocking”,
too, my precious wifie- If husband was only there he would fill
it full! Best love & a Merry Christmas to all- Enjoy yourself, my
darling, & don't forget husband- Love & Kisses for Mama & Son-
div1.closer:
Ever your own
husband & devoted husband, Walter of Arizona.
P.S. Mr
Gatewood
sends his
very best re-
-gards & a merry
Christmas to
you-
W. of A.
